channel.title: Nature Communications
channel.description:
Nature Communications is an open access, multidisciplinary journal dedicated to publishing high-quality research in all areas of the biological, health, physical, chemical and Earth sciences. Papers published by the journal aim to represent important advances of significance to specialists within each field.

We are committed to providing an efficient service for both authors and readers. Our team of independent editors make rapid and fair publication decisions. Prompt dissemination of accepted papers to a wide readership and beyond is achieved through a programme of continuous online publication.

item.title: Air-dried high-strength black MXene aerogel for spatiotemporal infrared information management
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 05 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-64754-8

A lightweight and high-strength Ti3C2Tx aerogel is prepared by air-drying methods for multi-spatiotemporal infrared information management.
item.dc:title: Air-dried high-strength black MXene aerogel for spatiotemporal infrared information management
item.dc:creator: Chunxiao Wu
Huhu Cheng
Qihua Liao
Chuanxin Weng
Bing Lu
Tianlei Guang
Yan Li
Liangti Qu

item.title: Alignment of edge dislocations – the reason lying behind composition inhomogeneity induced low thermal conductivity
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 05 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-64749-5

Exemplified by Bi0.4Sb1.6Te3, the authors reveal the reason for low thermal conductivity induced by compositional inhomogeneity lies in randomly aligned edge dislocations induced by random composition distribution.
item.dc:title: Alignment of edge dislocations – the reason lying behind composition inhomogeneity induced low thermal conductivity
item.dc:creator: Siqi Liu
Wei-Di Liu
Wanyu Lyu
Liang-Cao Yin
Yicheng Yue
Han Gao
Meng Li
Xiao-Lei Shi
Qingfeng Liu
Ning Wang
James D. Riches
Dmitri V. Golberg
Zhi-Gang Chen

item.title: A quantitative comparison of the fingerprint of twinned microstructures through surface and three-dimensional techniques
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 05 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-64740-0

Accurately assessing the microstructural fingerprint of materials is critical for supporting materials design. Here, the authors report the topological differences in 3D and 2D reconstructions of twin networks and reveal the biases embedded in surface views of 3D domain structures.
item.dc:title: A quantitative comparison of the fingerprint of twinned microstructures through surface and three-dimensional techniques
item.dc:creator: Duncan A. Greeley
Hi T. Vo
Rodney J. McCabe
Matthew M. Schneider
Carlos N. Tomé
Laurent Capolungo
